Feb 25 2008

Flight of the Conchords show sells out in 45 minutes

Published by wkschwartz at 7:57 pm under Events, Speakers

According to A&O Chairman Alex White, Flight of the Concords tickets sold out in 45 minutes. A&O thanks all those who came out and waited in line and congratulates those who got tickets! We know that many people waited in line and were unable to get tickets. We have started a ticket waiting list. If you have extra tickets or want to be on the waiting list, please email z-kahn@northwestern.edu. This morning we were asked many questions about why we chose to run ticketing as we did. We hope the answers below are helpful.

Frequently asked questions about the Flight of the Conchords show

Why were tickets $10?

A&O is funded by the student activities fee that all NU students pay each quarter, so we aim to keep prices as low as possible.

Why could people buy four tickets per Wildcard?

After BJ Novak sold out so quickly, A&O halved the number of tickets each person could purchase. Since people have classes, midterms and other commitments, it wouldn’t make sense for everyone to come to wait in line (plus it would be chaos). Several people in line bought two or three tickets, but most people sent one person to wait in line for four people.

Why is A&O checking Wildcards at the door?

As a stipulation for our events, artists almost always insist that the event be closed for two reasons:

First, because ticket prices are so low, many non-Northwestern students would be ecstatic to see such a cheap show and artists would of course rather have a show downtown where they can charge $30 a ticket.

Second, artists often have a second performance or planned future show in Chicago and don’t want to oversaturate the market.

Our priority is the students of Northwestern and we want to make sure they get a seat over someone’s friend from another school.

Will more tickets become available? Why isn’t it in a bigger venue?

A&O would love to sell 2,000 tickets. We want as many people as possible to see the acts we bring. However, a larger venue just doesn’t exist. The seated capacity of Cahn is 1011. Pick-Staiger seats 998. Welsh-Ryan is the most expensive venue and scheduling conflicts prohibited us from holding this event in that venue. A&O has been pushing for a multi-purpose, 2000-seat venue to be built on campus. You can help by emailing campus-activities@northwestern.edu to ask for a larger venue.

Please do not contact campus-activities@northwestern.edu for ticket requests, instead email z-kahn@northwestern.edu to get on a waiting list. Any other issues please contact campus-activities@northwestern.edu and your concerns will be delivered to the appropriate people.
